title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". The Congress finds serious shortages of qualified foster and adoptive parents, with a decrease in foster parents despite an increase in children in foster care. In 2001, only 50,000 children were adopted out of foster care while 126,000 children were awaiting adoption. As of 2001, there were 126,000 children waiting for adoption, with an average of 44 months in foster care. The increase in adoptions from foster care has led to a greater need for post-adoption services and skilled service providers. One Church, One Child is a national organization focused on foster care and adoption. One Church, One Child is a community-based foster care and adoption ministry founded in Chicago in 1980 by Father George Clements. Their mission is to provide services for at-risk children and support adoptive, foster, and kinship families. Over 140,000 children have been placed in adoptive families through their programs. The federally-funded grant program supports programs for recruiting foster and adoptive parents based on the One Church, One Child concept, benefiting abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of qualified parents. SEC. 479B. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS are added to Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act to support programs for recruiting foster and adoptive parents, benefiting abused and neglected children. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents through networks of public, private, and faith-based organizations, offering support services to children and families. The term 'eligible entity' refers to a State or local government, public agency, nonprofit organization, or private entity, including charitable or faith-based organizations, that submits an application to the Secretary with required information for grants to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents. The eligible entity must provide a project description outlining programs and services for children and prospective adoptive/foster parents, as well as demonstrate coordination efforts. The entity will coordinate and cooperate with State and local entities for foster parent and adoptive parent recruitment programs, and with the national clearinghouse. They will also maintain records, submit reports, and cooperate with reviews and audits as required by the Secretary for oversight. The term 'State' in this section refers to all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the US Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary is authorized up to $20,000,000 annually from 2005 to 2009 for oversight purposes. Grant funds are available for 3 years to eligible entities. Entities receiving grants must return any unspent funds and earnings to the Secretary after two fiscal years. The Secretary will redistribute these funds to eligible entities in need. Religious organizations must not face discrimination when receiving awards. The Secretary will consider religious organizations equally for grants under this section, as long as they comply with the Establishment Clause. State or local governments cannot discriminate against religious organizations seeking funding for programs under this section. The organization with a religious character cannot be required to change its internal governance or remove religious symbols to receive a grant or participate in a funded program. Funds provided to religious organizations for programs must not be used for sectarian activities. Religious organizations must adhere to fiscal regulations similar to other non-governmental organizations when using the funds. Religious organizations receiving funds must keep the money separate from other funds. SEC. 479C. National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Recruitment Programs; Annual Report to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment at the national level. Private entities, including charitable and faith-based organizations, coordinate activities for recruiting foster and adoptive parents and providing post-placement support. They also offer technical assistance, training, and best practices for grantees in this area. The curr_chunk focuses on collecting data on the effectiveness of programs funded under section 479B, including the number of children placed, foster and adoptive parents recruited, and other data required for evaluation. The curr_chunk discusses the selection of a nationally recognized, nonprofit organization to assist the Secretary in preparing reports on adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment programs. The curr_chunk highlights the criteria for selecting an organization to provide consultation and training to faith-based and community organizations for adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment. The curr_chunk discusses the funding authorization and reporting requirements for programs based on the One Church, One Child model. The authorized appropriations are limited to $1,000,000 annually from 2005 to 2009, and annual reports must be submitted to Congress detailing the number of entities receiving grants under the program. The curr_chunk specifies the reporting requirements for programs funded under section 479B, including the number of foster parents, adoptive families recruited, children placed, and outcomes of placements.
